Sends a status message back to
the client when it connects. This includes information about
the ciphers used and various session parameters. The output
is in

format so this option can be used
with a web browser. The special

"/renegcert" turns on client cert validation, and
"/reneg" tells the server to request
renegotiation. The

option cannot be used
with this option.

Emulates a simple web server.
Pages will be resolved relative to the current directory,
for example if the

flag is
used, the files are sent directly, and should contain any

response headers (including status
response line). If the

option is used, the
response headers are generated by the server, and the file
extension is examined to determine the

header. Extensions of "html", "htm", and
"php" are "text/html" and all others are
"text/plain". In addition, the special

"/stats" will return status
information like the

option. Neither of these

Names. You may want to disable

Windows

implementations crashing when
this extension is larger than 1024 bytes.

implementations do not send the mandatory close_notify alert
on shutdown. If the application tries to wait for the
close_notify alert but the peer closes the connection
without sending it, an error is generated. When this option
is enabled the peer does not need to send the close_notify
alert and a closed connection will be treated as if the
close_notify alert was received. For more information on
shutting down a connection, see

. This is mostly useful

a certain prefix).

Simple echo server that sends

. Cannot

Switch on asynchronous mode.
Cryptographic operations will be performed asynchronously.
This will only have an effect if an asynchronous capable
engine is also used via the

option. For test
purposes the dummy async engine (dasync) can be used (if
available).

The maximum size of data
fragment to send. See

The size used to split data for
encrypt pipelines. If more data is written in one go than
this value then it will be split into multiple pipelines, up
to the maximum number of pipelines defined by max_pipelines.
This only has an effect if a suitable cipher suite has been
negotiated, an engine that supports pipelining has been
loaded, and max_pipelines is greater than 1. See

The maximum number of
encrypt/decrypt pipelines to be used. This will only have an
effect if an engine has been loaded that supports pipelining
(e.g. the dasync engine) and a suitable cipher suite has
been negotiated. The default value is 1. See

p._value:
The server will exit after
receiving the specified number of connections, default
unlimited.

_values:

be used for connections. This will only have an effect if
the buffer size is larger than the size that would otherwise
be used and pipelining is in use (see

p._value:
Control the number of tickets
that will be sent to the client after a full handshake in
TLSv1.3. The default number of tickets is 2. This option
does not affect the number of tickets sent after a
resumption handshake.

Use the server’s cipher
preferences, rather than the client’s preferences.

_values:

p._value:
Signature algorithms to support
for client certificate authentication (colon-separated
list).

_values:
Specifies the elliptic curve to
use.

this is single curve, not a list.
For a list of all possible curves, use:

p._value:
$ openssl
ecparam -list_curves

_values:
This allows the list of TLSv1.2
and below ciphersuites used by the server to be modified.
This list is combined with any TLSv1.3 ciphersuites that
have been configured. When the client sends a list of
supported ciphers the first client cipher also included in
the server list is used. Because the client specifies the
preference order, the order of the server cipherlist is
irrelevant. See

This allows the list of TLSv1.3
ciphersuites used by the server to be modified. This list is
combined with any TLSv1.2 and below ciphersuites that have
been configured. When the client sends a list of supported
ciphers the first client cipher also included in the server
list is used. Because the client specifies the preference
order, the order of the server cipherlist is irrelevant. See

(1) command for more information. The
format for this list is a simple colon (":")
separated list of TLSv1.3 ciphersuite names.

parameter
file to use. The ephemeral

cipher suites
generate keys using a set of

parameters.
If not specified then an attempt is made to load the
parameters from the server certificate file. If this fails
then a static set of parameters hard coded into this command
will be used.

_values:
This option can only be used in
conjunction with one of the

options
above. With this option, this command will listen on a

port for incoming connections. Any
ClientHellos that arrive will be checked to see if they have
a cookie in them or not. Any without a cookie will be
responded to with a HelloVerifyRequest. If a ClientHello
with a cookie is received then this command will connect to
that peer and complete the handshake.

_values:

p._value: Require TLSv1.3 cookies.

Switches replay protection on
or off, respectively. Replay protection is on by default
unless overridden by a configuration file. When it is on,
OpenSSL will automatically detect if a session ticket has
been used more than once, TLSv1.3 has been negotiated, and
early data is enabled on the server. A full handshake is
forced if a session ticket is used a second or subsequent
time. Any early data that was sent will be rejected.

p._value:
Certain
commands are also recognized which perform special
operations. These commands are a letter which must appear at
the start of a line. They are listed below.

_values:
This command
can be used to debug

clients. To accept
connections from a web browser the command:

p._value:
openssl
s_server -accept 443 -www

can be used for
example.

_values:
Although
specifying an empty list of CAs when requesting a client
certificate is strictly speaking a protocol violation, some
clients interpret this to mean any

is acceptable. This is useful for
debugging purposes.

The session
parameters can printed out using the

Because this
program has a lot of options and also because some of the
techniques used are rather old, the C source for this
command is rather hard to read and not a model of how things
should be done. A typical

server program
would be much simpler.

p._value:
The output of
common ciphers is wrong: it just gives the list of ciphers
that OpenSSL recognizes and the client supports.

There should be
a way for this command to print out details of any unknown
cipher suites a client says it supports.

The
-no_alt_chains option was added in OpenSSL 1.1.0.

The
-allow-no-dhe-kex and -prioritize_chacha options were added
in OpenSSL 1.1.1.
